text: I made a shooting board that has a bunch
of attachments to tackle all different
types of projects
all right the base of the shooting board
is super simple I used some half-inch
plywood and ripped it to about 12 inches
wide and then I took my hand plane put
it on its side make sure it was fully
supported and then measured from the
sole of the plane to the edge of that
plywood I thought about like 9 and 3/4
inches and then I ripped some 3/4 MDF to
that width then I cut both the MDF and
the plywood to their final length which
was about 24 inches and I'm gonna have
more details on my website now here's a
tip that I learned from Rob Kosmas
shooting board video I'll put a link to
it down below but basically he creates a
tiny little rabbit on the edge of the
top portion of the shooting board and
this prevents the plane from eating away
and messing up the edge of the top part
of your shooting board so now the plane
the bottom of the soul will always ride
up against that part that's sticking out
and there's a tiny little gap there
that's preventing the blade from chewing
up the edge of the shooting board moving
on I wanted to make sure that the fence
was going to be really really square so
I decided to place it into a dado that
was going across the top of the MDF
portion of the jig so I just used a
half-inch router bit and then made that
dado and then I needed a piece to fit
into there so I found the straightest
piece of wood that I could find it hit
in my scrap in and then planed it down
so that it was just 1/2 inch thick
I needed a really really tight friction
fit so that when I use the half-inch
router bit on all the attachments it's
going to be a really great fit now this
fence just needs to be roughly the same
width of the jig but I just got a new
awesome stop block from Jonathan cats
Moses and I wanted to test it out so I
saw that it was not completely flush
against the MDF so I just played around
with the micro adjust settings moves it
in towards the bleed a tiny little bit
and then I was able to get that piece
perfectly flush awesome and now that
stop block is set for all the future
attachments I want to be able to use
this thin fence for planing thin stalks
so I temporarily put it into the groove
and marked about a quarter inch up from
the top of the MDF and then ripped it to
size at the table saw now it's time to
put it all together instead of using
clamps to hold the two pieces together I
decided that I was going to use
to help while the glue dried so I
pre-drilled all the holes and when you
drill sometimes the wood lifts up so I
just used a chisel to clean up all
around those holes so that the board was
gonna be perfectly flat this is super
important on the back so that the back
is flat and then I just put on a bunch
of glue made sure not to get all around
the edges because I really didn't want a
lot of squeeze out and then I just
temporarily clamped it into place and
then locked everything down with screws
so the screws are really just there to
act kind of as a clamp as the glue sets
up but I just wanted to make sure that
all the edges were going to be clamped
down also so I put on some extra clamps
and then I put in glue into the groove
that I made our dado that I made earlier
and then took that walnut fence and then
I just pinged it into place once the
glue set up it was time to add the last
part of the base and that's the bench
hook so I just found a scrap and cut it
to about 12 inches wide and then pre
drilled some holes in it glued it to the
bottom front of the jig and then just
locked it down with screws and the base
is done now it's time to work on all the
attachments the first attachment is just
a regular fence for cutting square and
grain and edge grain so I found a scrap
that was big enough and cleaned up and
squared up one end of it and then my
stop block was still in position from
cutting the main fence from before so I
just put it up against the fence
cut it to size and then brought it over
to the router table I still had that
half-inch bit there for when I made the
groove in the MDF and I just raised it
so that it was high enough that it would
fit into the main fence on the jig now
Jonathan cats Moses who is the maker of
that awesome stop block put out a
shooting board video recently and he
suggested putting a little chamfer on
the top of that piece there so make it
easier for the fence to go on I thought
that was a great idea and the piece went
on easily but there was still a friction
fit moving on to the miter attachment my
stop lock was still set to the width of
the MDF so I cut it to size and then I
just used a triangle to set a 45-degree
cut on it clamped it down and then cut
it away and literally that
man I just had to make the groove in the
bottom of it so that it would fit on to
the actual shooting board done moving on
to the third attachment this one is for
shooting long lighter as then is also
pretty easy to make so I just made one
cut that was 45 degrees creating two
45-degree edges that I could then attach
to each other but before I did that I
cut some triangles out of another scrap
piece of plywood to act as supports for
the jig I used this miter jig that I had
for my crosscut sled and used that stop
lock to make sure that when I flipped
over the plywood I had two equally sized
triangles that miter jig is basically
just a triangle and I showed how to make
it on my crosscut sled video time to
assemble this jig so I used regular wood
glue and then I also used just a little
bit of CA glue just to access a clamp
while the regular wood glue set up so I
put a triangle in between the two boards
to keep it at a perfect 45-degree angle
and then I used a brad nailer to hold it
into place and then I took those
triangles that I just cut on the
crosscut sled and I did the same thing
just glued and Brad nailed them into
place keeping the triangle in there so
that I know that it's perfectly 45
degrees flipped it over and then did the
same thing on the underside and it's
basically done it just needs a fence
that's going to be on the edge of it so
you put your workpiece on so that it
references a square edge and I thought
that just using CA glue would be enough
to put on this fence
spoiler alert it wasn't so you'll see
that in a bit but then I just made that
groove on the bottom of it so I could
attach it to the jig and it goes on
pretty easily there was just one issue
the main fence is siccing out through
the opening in the groove and it
prevents a workpiece from lying flat so
I decided to just take my hand saw and
just sawed off the little corner of the
fence and then just chisel it clean and
then my workpiece was able to lie flat
so now I did some testing to see how it
worked and that fence broke off so I
decided to just make a sturdier thicker
fence and this time I glued it on to the
edge of the plywood I used some painters
tape to temporarily hold it into place
and then I used a brad nailer to secure
it down so it's basically done there's
just a little
piece that's sticking out that I just
